what: 1. Identify the biases in your data
title: Introduction to multibias
text: epidemiological biases can generalized four main groups: Uncontrolled confounding (uc) Exposure misclassificaiton (em) Outcome misclassificaiton (om) Selection bias (sel) Multibias capable handling bias adjustment combinations four biases. Choose adjust() function corresponding biases interest using appropriate prefix. example, adjust_uc_sel() adjusts uncontrolled confounding selection bias. purposes demonstration, multibias includes datasets different bias combinations. given bias biases, includes biased data (e.g., df_uc_sel: missing confounder including un-selected subjects) source used derive biased data (e.g., df_uc_sel_source: including data missing confounder subjects selected). dataset variables defined similarly: X = binary exposure Y = binary outcome C1-C3 = binary confounders

title: Introduction to multibias
text: adjust() function multibias requires inputting observed, biased data data_observed object. specify dataframe identify key variables data.
code: df_observed <- data_observed(   df_uc_sel,   exposure = "X",   outcome = "Y",   confounders = c("C1", "C2", "C3") )

title: Introduction to multibias
text: Next, need information can used quantify assumed bias biases. two options .

title: Introduction to multibias
text: One option list assumed parameters corresponding bias equations. necessary bias equations provided documentation adjust() function. equations can derived using methods outlined article . example, bias parameters predict missing binary confounder U (vector u_coefs) study selection indicator S (vector s_coefs).

title: Introduction to multibias
text: second option specify validation data source data_validation object. order adjust given bias, validation data must corresonding missing data. example , validation data additional columns missing binary confounder U indicator S whether given individual selected study.
code: df_validation <- data_validation(   df_uc_sel_source,   true_exposure = "X",   true_outcome = "Y",   confounders = c("C1", "C2", "C3", "U"),   selection = "S" )

title: Introduction to multibias
text: Finally, can run multi-bias adjustment!

title: Introduction to multibias
text: observe bias-adjusted odds ratio effect X Y approximately 2. effect can compared effect observed biased data understand whether systematic error bringing observed effect closer null null.
code: adjust_uc_sel(   data_observed = df_observed,   u_model_coefs = u_coefs,   s_model_coefs = s_coefs ) #> $estimate #> [1] 2.001141 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 1.948436 2.055271 adjust_uc_sel(   data_observed = df_observed,   data_validation = df_validation ) #> $estimate #> [1] 2.001603 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 1.948854 2.055779

title: Introduction to multibias
text: Multibias performs bias adjustment via combination imputation /regression weighting. imputation involved, inherent randomness sampling. single run, therefore, produce exactly consistent result unless seed specified. Bootstrapping thus recommended quantify random error. Computational performance can improved via parallelization. adjusting via bias parameters, user can alternatively provide bias parameter value probability distribution. resulting confidence interval bootstrapping can quantify uncertainty random error systematic error. Check vignette article “Multibias Validation” demonstration approach.
code: n <- nrow(df_uc_sel) est <- vector() nreps <- 100  for (i in 1:nreps) {   df_bootstrap <- df_uc_sel[sample(seq_len(n), n, replace = TRUE), ]   df_observed <- data_observed(     df_bootstrap,     exposure = "X",     outcome = "Y",     confounders = c("C1", "C2", "C3")   )   results <- adjust_uc_sel(     df_observed,     df_validation   )   est[i] <- results$estimate }  # odds ratio estimate round(median(est), 2) #> [1] 2  # confidence interval round(quantile(est, c(.025, .975)), 2) #>  2.5% 97.5%  #>  1.94  2.06

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: demonstration multi-bias analysis, ’ll using 2013-2018 National Health Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) data linked CDC’s 2019 public-use mortality data. Within NHANES, data linked across demographics, 24-hour dietary recall, alcohol use, smoking use. ’ll assessing risk alcohol intake -cause mortality. ’re specifically going zoom comparison “extreme” drinkers “non-extreme” drinkers. filter participants reported alcohol past twelve months create sex-specific alcohol_extreme feature based USDGA guidelines 14 g/day women 28 g/day men. Participants “extreme drinkers” reported drinking 1.5x guidelines. Inspecting exposure-outcome counts, dealing rare exposure rare outcome. major age/gender differences among exposures. surprise, age higher die. Now tht ’ve loaded inspected data, let’s fit base model reference: logistic regression mortality alcohol, gender, age. exposure interest, observe odds ratio 1.6 (95% CI: 1.1, 2.2) indicating increased mortality risk among extreme drinkers, adjusted age gender. Note many important covariates considerations considered . family functions multibias requires inputting observed data data_observed() object.
code: library(multibias) library(dplyr) nhanes <- read.csv("nhanes.csv") nhanes_filtered <- nhanes |>   mutate(alcohol_extreme = case_when(     alcohol_day_total > 14 * 1.5 & gender_female == 1 ~ 1,     alcohol_day_total > 28 * 1.5 & gender_female == 0 ~ 1,     TRUE ~ 0   )) |>   filter(age >= 18) |>   filter(eligstat == 1) |>   filter(alcohol_12mo > 0) nhanes_filtered |>   group_by(alcohol_extreme, mortstat) |>   summarize(count = n()) |>   ungroup() |>   mutate(proportion = count / sum(count)) #> # A tibble: 4 × 4 #>   alcohol_extreme mortstat count proportion #>             <dbl>    <int> <int>      <dbl> #> 1               0        0  8412    0.856   #> 2               0        1   281    0.0286  #> 3               1        0  1089    0.111   #> 4               1        1    44    0.00448 nhanes_filtered |>   group_by(alcohol_extreme) |>   summarize(     age_mean = mean(age),     gender_prop = mean(gender_female)   ) #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   alcohol_extreme age_mean gender_prop #>             <dbl>    <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1               0     46.2       0.486 #> 2               1     45.1       0.454 nhanes_filtered |>   group_by(mortstat) |>   summarize(     age_mean = mean(age),     gender_prop = mean(gender_female)   ) #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   mortstat age_mean gender_prop #>      <int>    <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1        0     45.4       0.486 #> 2        1     66.2       0.375 base_mod <- glm(   mortstat ~ alcohol_extreme + gender_female + age,   data = nhanes_filtered,   family = binomial(link = "logit") )  exp(coef(base_mod)) #>     (Intercept) alcohol_extreme   gender_female             age  #>    0.0003640025    1.5603553141    0.6838661096    1.0852279381 exp(confint(base_mod)) #> Waiting for profiling to be done... #>                        2.5 %       97.5 % #> (Intercept)     0.0001952562 0.0006553778 #> alcohol_extreme 1.0999439503 2.1670092413 #> gender_female   0.5393792722 0.8637743150 #> age             1.0758586614 1.0950985762 df_obs <- data_observed(   data = nhanes_filtered,   exposure = "alcohol_extreme",   outcome = "mortstat",   confounders = c("age", "gender_female") )  print(df_obs) #> Observed Data #> ------------------ #> Exposure: alcohol_extreme  #> Outcome: mortstat  #> Confounders: age, gender_female  #> Data head:  #>   alcohol_extreme mortstat age gender_female #> 1               0        0  69             0 #> 2               1        1  54             0 #> 3               0        0  56             0 #> 4               0        0  61             1 #> 5               1        0  56             1

title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: important confounder, smoking, included analysis! Let’s demonstrate use validation data smoking information adjust uncontrolled confounding. Feature smoked_100cigs corresponds whether participant reported smoked 100 cigarettes throughout life. now put two objects multibias function named adjust_uc() adjust uncontrolled confounding. new bias-adjusted odds ratio (1.4) closer null base model. surprise considering extreme drinkers likely smokers, smoking increases risk death. Due strong correlations, part alcohol effect base model included effect smoking.
code: df_temp1 <- nhanes_filtered |>   filter(!is.na(smoked_100cigs))  df_val1 <- data_validation(   data = df_temp1,   true_exposure = "alcohol_extreme",   true_outcome = "mortstat",   confounders = c("age", "gender_female", "smoked_100cigs") ) set.seed(1234) adjust_uc(df_obs, df_val1) #> $estimate #> [1] 1.411961 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 1.003703 1.986279

what: 2. Adjust for uncontrolled confounding and exposure misclassification
title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: also wanted account fact people commonly -report alcohol use due social stigma? Let’s bring assumption wealthy, college-educated individuals susceptible stigma. ’ll say actual alcohol intake group, ’ll name alcohol_adj, 1.5 times reported. based feature, ’ll re-calculate exteme drinking indicator: alcohol_extreme_adj. now put two objects multibias function named adjust_uc_em() adjust uncontrolled confounding exposure misclassification. new bias-adjsted odds ratio even closer null.
code: df_temp2 <- nhanes_filtered |>   filter(!is.na(smoked_100cigs)) |>   mutate(alcohol_adj = if_else(     income == "$100,000 and Over" | education == "College graduate or above",     alcohol_day_total * 1.5,     alcohol_day_total   )) |>   mutate(alcohol_extreme_adj = case_when(     alcohol_adj > 14 * 2 & gender_female == 1 ~ 1,     alcohol_adj > 14 * 4 & gender_female == 0 ~ 1,     TRUE ~ 0   ))  df_val2 <- data_validation(   data = df_temp2,   true_exposure = "alcohol_extreme_adj",   true_outcome = "mortstat",   confounders = c("age", "gender_female", "smoked_100cigs"),   misclassified_exposure = "alcohol_extreme" ) set.seed(1234) adjust_uc_em(df_obs, df_val2) #> $estimate #> [1] 1.216906 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 0.8335281 1.7766173

what: 3. Adjust for uncontrolled confounding, exposure misclassification, and selection bias
title: Multibias example: NHANES
text: astute Epidemiologist reading along may noticed taken account NHANES sampling weights! NHANES select participants order group representative U.S. population, instead -sample -represented groups ensure representation across demographic categories. create selection bias exposure outcome related selection probability. two weights included two-day total nutrition survey; ’ll combine single feature. First, sample replacement based participant’s survey weight get dataframe representing selected participants. ’ll make dataframe participants selected . Let’s confirm sum two groups equals row count original dataframe. ’ll make ultimate dataframe indicator whether given subject selected based sampling procedure. usual, make data_validation object specify selection column, represents whether participant selected study. Now let’s see differential study selection led bias alcohol risk effect. now put two objects adjust_uc_em_sel() function adjust uncontrolled confounding, exposure misclassification, selection bias. selection bias based sampling weights seems pretty minor; bias-adjusted odds ratio effect alcohol mortality change much relative prior adjustment made.
code: df_temp3a <- nhanes_filtered |>   filter(!is.na(smoked_100cigs)) |>   mutate(alcohol_adj = if_else(     income == "$100,000 and Over" | education == "College graduate or above",     alcohol_day_total * 1.5,     alcohol_day_total   )) |>   mutate(alcohol_extreme_adj = case_when(     alcohol_adj > 14 * 2 & gender_female == 1 ~ 1,     alcohol_adj > 14 * 4 & gender_female == 0 ~ 1,     TRUE ~ 0   )) |>   mutate(     weight = if_else(weight_day2 == 0, weight_day1, weight_day2)   ) selected_sample <- sample(   x = df_temp3a$seqn,   size = nrow(df_temp3a),   replace = TRUE,   prob = df_temp3a$weight )  df_selected_sample <- data.frame() for (id in selected_sample) {   df_selected_sample <- rbind(     df_selected_sample,     df_temp3a[df_temp3a$seqn == id, ]   ) }  not_selected_sample <- df_temp3a$seqn[!(df_temp3a$seqn %in% selected_sample)] df_not_selected_sample <- df_temp3a[df_temp3a$seqn %in% not_selected_sample, ] length(not_selected_sample) + length(unique(selected_sample)) == nrow(df_temp3a) #> [1] TRUE df_selected_sample$selection <- 1 df_not_selected_sample$selection <- 0 df_temp3b <- rbind(df_selected_sample, df_not_selected_sample) df_val3 <- data_validation(   data = df_temp3b,   true_exposure = "alcohol_extreme_adj",   true_outcome = "mortstat",   confounders = c("age", "gender_female", "smoked_100cigs"),   misclassified_exposure = "alcohol_extreme",   selection = "selection" ) set.seed(1234) adjust_uc_em_sel(df_obs, df_val3) #> $estimate #> [1] 1.332608 #>  #> $ci #> [1] 0.9950054 1.7847580

title: Simultaneous Multi-Bias Adjustment
text: multibias package used adjust multiple biases causal inference working observational data. Bias refers case associational estimate effect equal causal estimate effect: (P(Y=1|X=1,C=0)/P(Y=1|X=0,C=0))≠(P(YX=1=1)/P(YX=0=1))(P(Y=1|X=1,C=0) / P(Y=1|X=0,C=0)) \neq (P(Y^{X=1}=1) / P(Y^{X=0}=1)) adjust() family functions output odds ratio estimates adjusted combination : uncontrolled confounding (uc), exposure misclassification (em), outcome misclassification (om), selection bias (sel). example, adjust_uc_om_sel() simultaneously adjusts uncontrolled confounding, outcome misclassificaiton, selection bias. package also includes several dataframes useful validating bias adjustment methods. dataframe contains different combinations bias identified prefixing system. bias combination, dataframe incomplete information (encountered real world) (e.g., df_uc) dataframe complete information used derive biased data (e.g., df_uc_source).

title: Simultaneous Multi-Bias Adjustment

Bias parameters. values come literature, validation data, expert opinion. parameter can represented single value probability distribution. See adjust() function documentation. Validation dataframe. purpose validation data use external data source transport necessary causal relationships missing observed data. observed data data_observed object bias parameters validation data data_validation object level bias-adjusted effect estimate confidence interval adjust() function output bias-adjusted exposure-outcome odds ratio confidence interval.

title: Adust for exposure misclassification. — adjust_em
text: data_observed Object class data_observed corresponding data perform bias analysis . data_validation Object class data_validation corresponding validation data used adjust bias observed data. , validation data data variables observed data, plus data true misclassified exposure corresponding observed exposure data_observed. x_model_coefs regression coefficients corresponding model: logit(P(X=1)) = δ0 + δ1X* + δ2Y + δ2+jCj, X represents binary true exposure, X* binary misclassified exposure, Y outcome, C represents vector measured confounders (), j corresponds number measured confounders. number parameters therefore 3 + j. level Value 0-1 representing full range confidence interval. Default 0.95.

title: Adust for exposure misclassification. — adjust_em

title: Adust for exposure misclassification. — adjust_em
text: Bias adjustment can performed inputting either validation dataset necessary bias parameters. Values bias parameters can applied fixed values single draws probability distribution (ex: rnorm(1, mean = 2, sd = 1)). latter advantage allowing researcher capture uncertainty bias parameter estimates. incorporate uncertainty estimate confidence interval, function run loop across bootstrap samples dataframe analysis. estimate confidence interval obtained median quantiles distribution odds ratio estimates.

text: data_observed Object class data_observed corresponding data perform bias analysis . data_validation Object class data_validation corresponding validation data used adjust bias observed data. , validation data data variables observed data, plus data true misclassified exposure corresponding observed exposure data_observed. also data confounder missing data_observed. u_model_coefs regression coefficients corresponding model: logit(P(U=1)) = α0 + α1X + α2Y, U binary unmeasured confounder, X binary true exposure, Y outcome. number parameters therefore equals 3. x_model_coefs regression coefficients corresponding model: logit(P(X=1)) = δ0 + δ1X* + δ2Y + δ2+jCj, X represents binary true exposure, X* binary misclassified exposure, Y outcome, C represents vector measured confounders (), j corresponds number measured confounders. number parameters therefore equals 3 + j. x1u0_model_coefs regression coefficients corresponding model: log(P(X=1,U=0)/P(X=0,U=0)) = γ1,0 + γ1,1X* + γ1,2Y + γ1,2+jCj, X binary true exposure, U binary unmeasured confounder, X* binary misclassified exposure, Y outcome, C represents vector measured confounders (), j corresponds number measured confounders. x0u1_model_coefs regression coefficients corresponding model: log(P(X=0,U=1)/P(X=0,U=0)) = γ2,0 + γ2,1X* + γ2,2Y + γ2,2+jCj, X binary true exposure, U binary unmeasured confounder, X* binary misclassified exposure, Y outcome, C represents vector measured confounders (), j corresponds number measured confounders. x1u1_model_coefs regression coefficients corresponding model: log(P(X=1,U=1)/P(X=0,U=0)) = γ3,0 + γ3,1X* + γ3,2Y + γ3,2+jCj, X binary true exposure, U binary unmeasured confounder, X* binary misclassified exposure, Y outcome, C represents vector measured confounders (), j corresponds number measured confounders. level Value 0-1 representing full range confidence interval. Two different options bias parameters available : 1) parameters separate models U X (u_model_coefs x_model_coefs) 2) parameters joint model U X (x1u0_model_coefs, x0u1_model_coefs, x1u1_model_coefs). Values bias parameters can applied fixed values single draws probability distribution (ex: rnorm(1, mean = 2, sd = 1)). latter advantage allowing researcher capture uncertainty bias parameter estimates. incorporate uncertainty estimate confidence interval, function run loop across bootstrap samples dataframe analysis. estimate confidence interval obtained median quantiles distribution odds ratio estimates.

text: data_observed Object class data_observed corresponding data perform bias analysis . data_validation Object class data_validation corresponding validation data used adjust bias observed data. , validation data data variables observed data, plus data : 1) true misclassified outcome corresponding observed outcome data_observed, 2) confounder missing data_observed, 3) selection indicator representing whether observation data_validation selected data_observed. u_model_coefs regression coefficients corresponding model: logit(P(U=1)) = α0 + α1X + α2Y, U binary unmeasured confounder, X exposure, Y binary true outcome. number parameters therefore equals 3. y_model_coefs regression coefficients corresponding model: logit(P(Y=1)) = δ0 + δ1X + δ2Y* + δ2+jCj, Y represents binary true outcome, X exposure, Y* binary misclassified outcome, C represents vector measured confounders (), j corresponds number measured confounders. number parameters therefore equals 3 + j. u0y1_model_coefs regression coefficients corresponding model: log(P(U=0,Y=1)/P(U=0,Y=0)) = γ2,0 + γ2,1X + γ2,2Y* + γ2,2+jCj, U binary unmeasured confounder, Y binary true outcome, X exposure, Y* binary misclassified outcome, C represents vector measured confounders (), j corresponds number measured confounders. number parameters therefore equals 3 + j. u1y0_model_coefs regression coefficients corresponding model: log(P(U=1,Y=0)/P(U=0,Y=0)) = γ1,0 + γ1,1X + γ1,2Y* + γ1,2+jCj, U binary unmeasured confounder, Y binary true outcome, X exposure, Y* binary misclassified outcome, C represents vector measured confounders (), j corresponds number measured confounders. number parameters therefore equals 3 + j. u1y1_model_coefs regression coefficients corresponding model: log(P(U=1,Y=1)/P(U=0,Y=0)) = γ3,0 + γ3,1X + γ3,2Y* + γ3,2+jCj, U binary unmeasured confounder, Y binary true outcome, X exposure, Y* binary misclassified outcome, C represents vector measured confounders (), j corresponds number measured confounders. number parameters therefore equals 3 + j. s_model_coefs regression coefficients corresponding model: logit(P(S=1)) = β0 + β1X + β2Y* + β2+jC2+j, S represents binary selection, X exposure, Y* binary misclassified outcome, C represents vector measured confounders (), j corresponds number measured confounders. number parameters therefore equals 3 + j. level Value 0-1 representing full range confidence interval. Default 0.95.

title: Adust for uncontrolled confounding, outcome misclassification, and selection bias. — adjust_uc_om_sel
text: Bias adjustment can performed inputting either validation dataset necessary bias parameters. Two different options bias parameters availale : 1) parameters separate models U Y (u_model_coefs y_model_coefs) 2) parameters joint model U Y (u1y0_model_coefs, u0y1_model_coefs, u1y1_model_coefs). approaches require s_model_coefs. Values regression coefficients can applied fixed values single draws probability distribution (ex: rnorm(1, mean = 2, sd = 1)). latter advantage allowing researcher capture uncertainty bias parameter estimates. incorporate uncertainty estimate confidence interval, function run loop across bootstrap samples dataframe analysis. estimate confidence interval obtained median quantiles distribution odds ratio estimates.

title: multibias: Simultaneous Multi-Bias Adjustment — multibias-package
text: Quantify causal effect binary exposure binary outcome adjustment multiple biases. functions can simultaneously adjust combination uncontrolled confounding, exposure/outcome misclassification, selection bias. underlying method generalizes concept combining inverse probability selection weighting predictive value weighting. Simultaneous multi-bias analysis can used enhance validity transparency real-world evidence obtained observational, longitudinal studies. Based work Paul Brendel, Aracelis Torres, Onyebuchi Arah (2023) doi:10.1093/ije/dyad001 .
